SPILL_LOC_DESC: Building  cleanout of Big John's Market overflowed. The business owner states that they thought they had somekind of sewer problem on Friday night as they could smell sewage. I wasnt until Saturday  when the  sewage was seen overflowing. Fire Department, Public Works, Fish and Game and Police Department  worked together to resolve the problem. Private sewer contractor was called to clear blockage, public works flushed storm drain and vacuumed Foss Creek
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: Building cleanout spilled into parking area, traveled to a nearby storm drain then flowed into Foss Creek. Sewage was contained the creek downstream of the overflow
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Water was contained to a Foss Creek down stream of big John's market
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: If your office get three copies of this document, it because this system kept shutting down and I could not recover the information  I did not save the document , so I would try again. That's why three attempts were made. BD
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Restored flow
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Private contractor cleared blockage, flushed storm drain with fresh water Used vacuum truck to recover all the contaminated water from the creek and drain. All water was pumped into the sanitary sewer or hauled to the wastewater treamtent plant for disposal. Fire marshall Linda Collister of the Healdsburg Fire Department  was the incident commander on this call. She made the notification to OES to distribute the information about the spill to the required agencies

SPILL_LOC_DESC: Spill occured from a private lateral adjacent to an easement  for a sewer that runs from Discovery to Fairchild Streets, between North and Yama Streets.
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: An existing break in a private sewer lateral in back yard of 818 North St.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Wastewater came out of the private lateral of 818 North St., which is in the back yard.  The wastewater flowed over the ground and into a dry drainage ditch.  The wastewater soaked into the ground in the drainage ditch before reaching an inlet into the City's storm drain system. Therefore, the wastewater did not reach any surface waters.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Roots in main sewer caused blockage.  Wastewater backed up in main and came out of a broken private lateral.
WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: Roots blocked the main. The wastewater backed up in the main and in a lateral and came out of a displaced joint in the lateral.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Restored flow;Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Affected soil and solids were removed and diposed of.  Regulatory agencies notified. Neghbors asked to not enter drainage channel for one week.  Caution tape put on both sides of drainage channel and at easement entry point.    CIWQS report was not finalized with in 24 hours because the cause of spill was uncertain. ie private lateral or sewer main

SPILL_LOC_DESC: Spill occurred out of cleanout from a private property sewer lateral at 607 Boyd Street. The majority of the spill  (750gal) was contained in a low depression at the cleanout and overflowed into the parking area of the apartment complex. Spill occurred during heavy rains.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Total amount that entered the storm drain system is questionable. Spill had stopped running when crews arrived at site, could not confirm that any portions of the spill had or had not entered the storm drain system,  Due to the grade only an assumption was made that possibly as little as 10 gallons may have made the storm drain. No sewage was detected in the storm drain system; storm drain was cleaned as a precaution.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Plumber broke blockage at 12:00 pm., plumber then notified agency of problem. Heavy roots, grease and pipe offset were found on Property side cleanout.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Inspected sewer using CCTV to determine cause;Restored flow;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system;Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: City crew was called by Economy Plumbing to assist with a lateral blockage and clean up. The plumber broke the blockage and drained the spill back into the lateral, approximately 500 gallons. City crews cleaned the remainder of the spill (240 gallons) from the surface areas.

SPILL_LOC_DESC: Private sewer lateral was installed on top of storm drain culvert grate at rear of property next to railroad tracks (Caltrain owned property). This pipe was left open and was not connected to the sewer main which resulted in sewage discharging directly into the storm drain culvert.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Private lateral line was left open and was not connected to sewer main.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-Up;Other (specify below);Property Owner Notified;Other Enforcement Agency Notified
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: We first discovered open lateral on May 21st. At this time we inspected, jetting, vacuumed and videoed storm lines downstream from spill location to City limit. Contacted San Mateo County Environmental Health and notify them of spill. Requested business to close and had the Belmont Building Official come out on May 22nd and red tag the building. Notified the City of San Mateo of spill since the storm system flows into their City. San Mateo Environmental Health and SVCW (treatment plant) took samples from the storm system. Waiting for those results.

RETURN_TO_SSS: No
SPILL_LOC_DESC: Spill occurred from a private lateral into a storm box culvert that is located under the building.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Our crew found sewage in the storm culvert through the storm drain inspection manhole on Hatch Lane and they started tracking the spill after they diked the area to contain the spill.  Our crews checked the sanitary sewer mains in the area and found that they were working properly.    They checked the upstream storm drain inlet and found that it was clear.  They proceed by doing a confine space entry and one of the employees walked up the box culvert and at approximately 100 feet found a cast iron private lateral that was abandoned and the end of it had fallen into the box culvert while the other end was still connected to a live private lateral.  The employee proceeded by disconnecting the portion of the pipe that was abandoned and plug the end that was connected to the live private lateral to prevent further overflows from the connection.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Contained all or portion of spill
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Our crews contained the spill in the box culvert upon arrival at Hatch lane and Burlingame Avenue and California.  They set up one Vac-con at the catch basin on Hatch lane and the other Vac-Con at California Drive and Burlingame Avenue.  Then one of the employees washed down the box culvert vacuuming all the water at both locations.  We estimated using 2,000 gallons of water to wash down the spill which they were able to vacuum the water and the spill from the two locations with the aid of the Vac-Cons.  They also disinfected the area as a precaution.

APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: Crack in Street next to newly installed manhole.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: District Contractor failed to reconnect one of the laterals for the home at 110 El Toyonal Dr. after installing new 8  pvc main.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Restored flow;Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: District Contractor failed to reconnect one of the laterals for the home at 110 El Toyonal dr. after installing new 8  pvc main. H/O at # 28 Vallecito Lane notice a wet spot in the street on 12/20/2012.He did not inform the District untill 1/4/2013 at 8:30am. During the time between the h/o noticing the street and the time that we were informed the o/f had run down the street and onto the dirt area next to the street.We arrived on site with the District inpector at 9:00 am who called the contractor who then arrived and reconnected the lateral and restored flow at 11:30am. We estimated the amount of o/f to be 15 gals per day times 15 days or 225 gals. We washed down and vac'd street, curb and gutter,and cleaned up the dirt area on the side of the street.

RETURN_TO_SSS: Yes
SPILL_LOC_DESC: Private property line c/o overflowed into City curb/gutter and drain inlet.
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: Spill appeared at private property line clean out.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Spill was captured in City storm system
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Inspected sewer using CCTV to determine cause;Restored flow;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Responded imediatly and broke plug. A Vac Con responded to clean storm systen and curb and gutter. City storm main tested positive for ammonia. Permenente creek was tested for ammonia upstream and down stream of storm outfall. Results were negative.

RETURN_TO_SSS: No
SPILL_LOC_DESC: Sewage overflowed from a private property line 6  clean out at an apartment complex
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Spill entered Permanente Creek
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Inspected sewer using CCTV to determine cause;Restored flow;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Cleared lateral blockage immediately, tested City storm manhole 50' upstream of Permanente creek and got positive test for ammonia. We set up 2 Vac- Cons approximately 1 mile downstream at San Luis Ave. We set up a sandbag dam and ran de-chlorinated water at spill point. Using ammonia test strips we tested creek. Test at setup site was negative. As the water reached our dam we got a positive test. The water partially overwhelmed our dam. We removed approximately 8,000 gallons of water from the San Luis site and then moved downstream to Old Middlefield Road and Permanente Creek. We removed another 6,000 gallons from that site. Follow up testing with ammonia test strips was negative at the San Luis site. Had one minor positive test further downstream followed by a negative test. Additional fecal coliform tests will be taken today 8/7/13 at 10:00am.

SPILL_LOC_DESC: Private sewer lateral serving 2340 Marinship Way illegal sewer connection to a storm drainage system.  Sewage positively confirmed that the sewage leaving 2340 Marinship Way is creating an illicit discharge to a storm drainage system on Marinship Way.The SD K CB with the positive dye test results appears to be a storm drainage line that may have been plumbed directly to MH 101 at one time.  City Crews have scoured the area trying to figure out where the CB flows to.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Private sewer lateral serving 2340 Marinship Way illegal sewer connection to a storm drainage system.  Sewage positively confirmed that the sewage leaving 2340 Marinship Way is creating an illicit discharge to a storm drainage system on Marinship Way.The SD K CB with the positive dye test results appears to be a storm drainage line that may have been plumbed directly to MH 101 at one time.  City Crews have scoured the area trying to figure out where the CB flows to. No positive dye tests to any storm drain leading to the final outfall at Richardson Bay.  Further the private sewer lateral serving 2340 Marinship Way illegal sewer connection to a storm drainage system. Property owner has discontinued the use of the sewer lateral.  Portable toilets are onsite as of 11/19/2015.  A new sewer lateral is required to be installed and tied into the publicly maintained Sausalito Marin City Sanitary District interceptor located on Marinship Way.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Plumbed illegally to an abandoned private storm drainage system
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Property Owner Notified

RETURN_TO_SSS: No
SPILL_LOC_DESC: PLSD from 216A/216B, 218/220/20A, 222/224, 226/228 Glen Drive PCL 02/05/2016 The sewage was noticed by a tenant on the other side of the Glen Creek on 2/01/2016 at around 12:00 noon.  They started thinking that maybe someone should look at it on 02/05/2016.  The tenant called SSC  directly at 2:30pm on 2/05/2016.  SSC called the City Sewer Crew Supervisor immediately.  City Sewer Crew Staff investigated the PLSD within 5 minutes of receiving the call from SSC. The SSC was onsite by 2:50.  The PCL serving 216 A/ 216B, 218/220, 222/224 and possibly 226/228 Glen Drive had become detached and raw sewage had been flowing uncontrolled into the adjacent Glen Creek.  The overflow was quantified at 6,000 gallons released from 6 single units, and reported as such to the California Office of Emergency Services (OES) OES control number 16-0792  yesterday at 5:02pm, with the classification designation of a  Category I PLSD due to the sewage overflow making contact with the adjacent Glen Creek.  The Glen Creek flows under the Girard Avenue Bridge,  then down the Turney Street 30-inch storm drainage pipe, to final out fall at the Turney Street Boat ramp. I ordered the immediate repair to the disconnected PCL last night at 3:00 pm and was able to have a temporary repair in place by 5:15 pm.  The City will be billing back the property owners that share this portion of the PCL for the temporary repairs performed last night.  The City will be have other requirements of all of the property owners being served by this portion of the PCL in the very near future.
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: Broken Private Common Sewer Lateral (PCL) serving 216A/216B, 218/220/20A, 222/224, 226/228 Glen Drive
SSO_PLSD_SOURCE_PLSD: High Density Residential (5 or more units - Apartments, Condos, etc.)
SSO_PLSD_SOURCE_EXPLAIN: 216A/216B, 218/220/20A, 222/224, 226/228 Glen Drive, Sausalito Private Common Sewer Lateral (PCL)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Other (specify below);Restored flow;Property Owner Notified;Other Enforcement Agency Notified
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: The City ordered the immediate repair to the disconnected PCL last night at 3:00 pm and was able to have a temporary repair in place by 5:15 pm. The City will be have other requirements of all of the property owners being served by this portion of the PCL in the very near future.

SPILL_LOC_DESC: Mar Brisas HMA located at 924 N. 4th Street, Grover Beach, CA 93433.  Spill occurred at manhole located just outside of the lift station.  Sewage discharged out of a 1  pickhole and flowed down the curb/gutter approximately 500' where it was stopped by a naturally ocurring earthen dam.  The remaining flow showed evidence of evaporation.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Flow was contained by a naturally ocurring earthen dam.  The discharge showed evidence of evaporation.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Lift Station bubbler control was left in the  off  position causing the manhole to overflow.  When discovered, this switch was returned to the  on  position and the lift station was pumped down.  Flow was returned to normal operations.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Restored flow
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Crews arrived on-site and spill was already mitigated.  No flow was visibly observed.  Crews noted that a naturally occuring earthen dam had prevented the discharge from entering any surface water.  Evidence showed the SSO to be minimal with a total loss of gallons to be 310 and a flow of less than 1 gpm.  The discharge was contained by the naturally ocuring dam and appeared to have evaporated.

SPILL_LOC_DESC: From the private lateral cleanout at the Valley Mobile (Home) Park. 220 Williams Road, Salinas, Ca. 93905
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Spill flowed from private lateral cleanout across a City sidewalk to the curb and gutter and to a nearby storm drain.  All surfaces were washed down and the wash water recovered for proper disposal.  About 2,600 ft. of storm pipe was accessible for flushing and recovery.  Staff flushed and removed approximately 2,000 gallons of wash water from the storm system pipe.  The remaining distance was flushed by a significant amount of aricultural irrigation water that was running through the storm system and discharged to Reclamation Ditch 1665.  Due to the amount of water present and moving in the Reclamation Ditch and the remote location of the discharge, containment and recovery was not possible.  The discharge was intermittent for a period of about 11 hours.  Staff estimates a recovery of approximately 100 gallons of the effluent discharge.

SPILL_LOC_DESC: Shower pan located in residence as reported by property owner from renter on August 17, 2012 apparently caused by December 19, 2010 SSO.
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: Shower pan located in residence as reported by property owner from renter on August 17, 2012 apparently caused by December 19, 2010 SSO.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: The final destination of the spill is unknown.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Influent pump room at the Wastewater Treatment Plant Headworks flooded causing catastrophic failure of the pumps. Major storm event and inflow and infiltration caused the collection system to quickly surcharge and spill from manholes throughout the system.  likely that home did not have required backwater valve installed to prevent backflow into structure.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Contained all or portion of spill
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: As part of the due diligence regarding the investigation into the cause and magnitude of the overall SSO of 12/19/10, SSLOCSD contacted residents in the area of flooding (via phone, e-mail and in person, if necessary) in order to interview residents and report any spills, if required. After many attempts to contact all persons who might have been impacted by the flooding, the most recent contact by SSLOCSD was 2/29/12, so that CIWQS entry could be completed in a timely fashion, as requested by SWRCB. The property owner, Ms. Alana Reynolds, contacted SSLOCSD staff later on 08/17/12...nearly 6 months from the most recent contact and nearly 20 months since the incident.Information she provided was based upon discussions with her tenant at the time.The tenant could not be reached for additional questions.SSLOCSD is filing this SSO in CIWQS in order to best document the incident and provide as much information as is currently known.The facts as reported by the land owner could not be independently verified or corroborated by any independent parties.

The RP began clean up of the private area on the 19th at approximately 2:00 PM. On our return the morning of the 20th, the area had been properly cleaned.

RETURN_TO_SSS: Not Applicable - Spill did not reach a separate storm drainpipe
SPILL_LOC_DESC: the location of the SSO was at an excavation pit about 20 feet south of the intersection of Monterey Avenue and South Street, on the east edge of the Monterey Avenue pavement.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: During excavation for a subsurface water valve vault,  the backhoe operator exposed and broke a sewer lateral. the wastewater drained into the excavation pit.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: During excavation for a city waterworks new water-valve vault, the backhoe operator hit and broke a sewer lateral. The workers immediately shut off water to the nearby residences.
WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: A sewer lateral was exposed and broken during excavation for a water valve vault.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Contained all or portion of spill;Restored flow;Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: The wastewater was contained in the excavation pit directly below the broken lateral. The city water workers immediately turned off water to nearby residences and called the Collection System Supervisor. The Supervisor and another worker cut the broken lateral section and replaced it with plastic pipe of the same diameter. The water workers restored water service to the nearby residence and ultimately backfilled the excavation pit.

SPILL_LOC_DESC: Private sewer lateral from El Torito Restaurant backed up and spilled directly from parking lot cleanout, down embankment and into ocean. Exact details (spill amount and start time) are unknown and thus are being estimated in this report.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Ocean near McAbee Beach
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Debris clog in private sewer lateral
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-Up;Restored flow;Property Owner Notified
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: City Fire Department contained flow until it could be stopped, and required El Torito to stop all water use on premisis. County Health posted beach off-limits to users. City communicated with US Coast Guard and MBNMS. PW staff and Building Official responded. Building Official red-tagged/closed building until licensed plumber performed needed fixes and provided update to City to demonstrate plumbing in working order. Owner informed Env Reg Mngr that they hired plumber and disaster clean-up specialists to perform work. City taking further actions and will continue to require owner to perform regular maintenance and report to City/Building Official.

City sent follow-up Warning Letter to Owner 08/14/15 regarding illegal discharge to ocean, stating if occurs again, Citation will be issued.

Continuing problem at this location due to old sewer lateral and original configuration which needs more efficient connection to City sewer. City planning City sewer rehab at the location of this private lateral, and rehab plan will prioritize the project and assist with PLSD issues in this location. The OES, County Health, RWQCB were all contacted. (This PLSD report replaces SSO 816340 since failure was in private lateral.)

RETURN_TO_SSS: No
SPILL_LOC_DESC: Per Fire crew, spill found spill coming out of MH cover in open space btwn Malloway Rd and Syvan Road (sewer MH approx 100 yards south of 4105 Malloway Rd); spill entered storm drain at SW corner of Spruance and Farragut (in front of Navy Lodge).
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: Collection system of Federal Govt Installation (Navy/Army Military Housing) had blockage that caused spill from their manhole between Sylvan Rd and Malloway Rd
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Fire Dept estimated 15,000 gallons spilled to Federal Govt storm drain and discharged to drainage channel near Aguajito Rd; Fire Dept implemented full diversion back into a different sanitary sewer manhole and recovered 5,000 gallons immediately. City PPW staff located downhill storm drain outfall to dry drainage channel, where the sewage traveled approx. 20 feet upon outlet and immediately soaked into the soil.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Blockage in Federal Govt/Installation sanitary sewer collection system at Army/Navy Military Housing called La Mesa Village. Start time of spill is unknown. City Fire arrived at 14:54 and implemented a diversion of the spilling sewage back into another sanitary sewer manhole and continued doing this until infrastructure assistance was received from City of Seaside PPW crew.
WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: Blockage of gravity line in Fed Govt Installation sewage collection system
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-Up;Mitigated Effects of Spill;Contained all or portion of spill;Restored flow;Returned Portion of Spill to Sanitary Sewer System;Property Owner Notified;Other Enforcement Agency Notified
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Monterey Fire Dept responded. Monterey County Health Department staff (Lindsay Cunningham) was notified and on-scene. La Mesa Prop Mngt requested plumber, who arrived, but needed greater assistance. City of Seaside provided mutual aid PW sewer truck to assist with restoring flow. MCHD staff Marni Flagg released Fire resources, was to stay on-scene until spill cleaned up, and advised Fire MCHD would obtain OES control #.

RETURN_TO_SSS: No
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: City's pump station had failed due to power outage by Edison.  Sewer had backed up into a private property lateral and spilled out into the patio area from a clean out with loose cap.  Private property owner had hired a plumber and the plumber put the cap back on at 4:00 pm and spill was stopped.  Later the City sewer crew discovered that the spilled sewer at the private property patio had found its way into the area drain sump pump on site and the pump transfered the SSO into the stree right of way which entered the storm drain and ended at the beach outfall aproximately 300 feet from the spill.  at the time of this discovery the sewer spill had percolated into the sand at the beach.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Restored flow
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Closed off the area  and disinfected the paved surface and the sand in the beach within 48 hours from the spill.

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Restored flow;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system;Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: It was necessary for the sanitary sewer system agency to stay all night at the overflow scene, due to the fact the owner of the small mall would not respond to any of the messages that were left for him.  The overflow was coming out of a clean out and going across the sidewalk, and into the curb line, and into a catch basin, just south of the west side driveway.  The County Sewer was not the problem, but due to the fact the sewage was in the cub line, County Sewer agency needed to prevent it from induction into the catch basin.  After getting response from Mr. Golden (owner of the property), he sent Rescue Rooter out at the location.  Rescue Rooter cleared the lateral stoppage and the area was washed and clears of any debris.

Approximately 800 gallons of the spill was contained in the loading dock and about 100 gallons entered the public right-of-way.  Of the 100 gallons that entered the street, 50 gallons was contained, 50 gallons entered the storm drain system.
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: The spill appearance point was a manhole located in the hospital loading dock.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: The spill was diverted at the City's Pico-Kenter diversion and routed to the Santa Monica Urban Runoff Recycling Facility (SMURRF) for treatment.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: The spill was caused by a blockage in the hospital's lateral connection to the City main.  Hospital facility staff stated that there was a buildup of wipes in their line.

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-Up;Contained all or portion of spill;Other (specify below);Restored flow;Other Enforcement Agency Notified
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: UCLA Hospital facility's staff contained and vacuumed up a majority of the spill using a combination of portable wet vacuums, a small street sweeper, and absorbent socks.  City Wastewater staff disinfected and washed down the public right-of-way.  OES, LA County Department of Health Services, and the LA Regional Water Quality Control Board were notified.  The spill was diverted by the City's Pico-Kenter diversion and routed to the Santa Monica Urban Runoff Recycling Facility (SMURRF).

SPILL_LOC_NAME: Ojai Park and Ride Parking lot
RETURN_TO_SSS: No
SPILL_LOC_DESC: The spill occurred in the Ojai park and ride parking lot.  A private lateral clean out in parking lot discharged and ran down to a storm drain that discharges to a drainage ditch that transits the Ojai Valley Inn Golf Course.
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: Private lateral clean out serving the Ojai Ford dealership (out of business) building complex.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Drainage ditch transiting the Ojai Valley Inn Golf Course.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: 0800 - Jim receives a call from Rueben Martinez of the City of Ojai.  Rueben reports that there is sewage coming out of a clean out located in the park and ride parking lot adjacent to the closed ford dealership.    0815 - Jim, Mark and Tom arrive at parking lot and assess the situation.  Mark and Tom open Manhole O-29-06 where the OVSD system starts and the dealership lateral discharges.  The manhole was clear with no sign of surcharge and no flow coming from the private lateral.    0820 - The affected area was secured then containment and assessment efforts started.  Mark noted and photographed that all the solids had been captured and filtered through a large amount of leaves prior to entering the storm drain. No solids were noted downstream of the entry point.    0824 - Dwight sprays down the affected area with a hospital grade disinfectant.    0834 - The Vactor arrives on site and the clearing of the lateral commences using the jet rodder.  An obstruction is encountered at 89 feet and is cleared.  The line is then jet rodded out to 150 feet to ensure no other blockages exist.       0847 - Wash down and vacuuming of the area started.  The previously disinfected solids are washed down to the Vactor using the storm drain vault as a collection chamber.  The vault is then completely disinfected and vacuumed out.    0905 - Wash down complete and clean up and break down of equipment started.    0912 - CS returns to normal duties and reporting process started.    1100 - After consulting with the Treatment Plant Chemist David Harter and touring the affected down stream drainage ditch 6 initial water samples were taken. 2 above the entry point and 4 below the entry point.

RETURN_TO_SSS: Yes
SPILL_LOC_DESC: The clean out near the building at 614 Sutter street overflowed into the landscaped area, sidewalk and gutter.  The spill was isolated in the storm drain DI.   The Down stream DI was checked for wastewater using a YSI meter and found no positive readings.  On arrival, the homeowners cleanout was overflowing onto the sidewalk and gutter.  City crew set up the vactor truck to contain the spill at the DI location.  The second vactor flushed the service line to clear the back up.  Area was sprayed with disinfectant and washed down to clean up debris.  The service lateral was CCTV'ed and no problems were found.  Possible problem could have been from a fire which occurred the previous week. Debris from the fire could have been pushed into the service lateral causing the backup.     Estimated that 5 gallons lost due to saturation in the landscape area.  City crew Used a YSI meter to check the next storm drain DI sump, and found no evidence that the spill had left the upstream DI sump
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: DI Sump.

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: No other response is needed, debris kicked in clean out because of a fire that happened a few days earlier.

RETURN_TO_SSS: Not Applicable - Spill did not reach a separate storm drainpipe
SPILL_LOC_DESC: Private manhole located behind 400 Crestridge overflowed on the hillside and flowed down the horse trail.
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: Private main line back up, caused overflow out of a Private manhole.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: On Arrival, private manhole located behind 400 Crestridge was overflowing onto the hillside and running down the horse trail.  Per city policy, when a private spill leaves the residents property and could enter a water way, the city will start procedures to prevent the overflow from entering the waterway.  City flushed the main line on the property and cleared the problem.  Root intrusion had caused the overflow.  City set waddles and sprayed overflow area with disinfectant.  City clean up area off private property.  Complex will be cleaning the property behind the manhole.  This was completed on the day of the spill.  City pulled waddles and CCT'ed the main line to make sure of no other problems.  City estimates that 130 gallons was saturated in the hillside and horse trail.  Debris was picked up, but because of the location, no equipment was able to reach spill to recover spill.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Private manhole located behind 400 Crestridge Ln  overflowed on the hillside and flowed down the horse trail.
SSO_PLSD_SOURCE_PLSD: High Density Residential (5 or more units - Apartments, Condos, etc.)
SSO_PLSD_SOURCE_EXPLAIN: Location of Main line and manholes are on private property
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Mitigated Effects of Spill;Restored flow;Returned Portion of Spill to Sanitary Sewer System;Property Owner Notified

RETURN_TO_SSS: Yes
SPILL_LOC_DESC: A grease interceptor overflowed into a courtyard area with a area drain that led to a Storm drain system.  The DI downstream of the spill had been boarded off from a prior rehab project, and was holding the overflow in the pipe.  This caused the DI upstream to overflow in the gutter line, and the resident called in the problem.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: On Saturday the 22nd, Sewer department called and investigated the overflow, removed the overflow from the storm drain pipe with a combo-flushing unit, the spill was stopped at 6:55 pm and the site was cleaned and disinfected.    At this time the crew could not find the cause.  On Monday the 24th, the cause of the overflow was tracted down and the cause was a grease interceptor that was overflowing into the courtyard and into an area drain that was connected to the city storm drain system.  City crew set the combo-flushing truck at the DI sump, and cleaned up storm sytem and disinfected the storm drain system.  The boards in the DI were removed.  Estamating 350 gal spill that was fully contained because of the boards in the down stream DI.
SSO_PLSD_SOURCE_PLSD: High Density Residential (5 or more units - Apartments, Condos, etc.)
WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: Private grease interceptor on the property.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-Up;Contained all or portion of spill;Returned All Spill to Sanitary Sewer System;Property Owner Notified

SPILL_LOC_DESC: A manhole in the apartment complex property.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Restored flow;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: The sewer overflow was traced down stream of entry point and contained in the storm system at two locations by 1450 hours.  Our storm lines were sandbagged at approximately 2825 feet and at 7500 feet down stream.  Roto-Rooter was on scene when we arrived and cleared the blockage at 1330 hours.       Flow was restored at approximately 1330 hours by ROTO-ROOTER.  The spill was estimated at 9000 gallons in this time frame. It was confirmed that no sewage had gotten past our containment after samples were analized by our city lab.  City crews flushed fresh water for the clean up towards our HVVC's and removed approximately 38,000 gallons from our storm system, clean up was completed by 2300 hours.  A private contractor called Clean Harbors Environmental Services was called out by the property manager to clean the private storm system on site.  They arrived at 1940 hours and completed the clean up 4/10/08 at 0030 hours.     City Environmental Compliance staff are currently working with the property management to have them on a regular maintenance schedule to clean their sewer lines and eliminate a second spill.

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: The small amount of sewer water that overflowed evaporated while city crew was on site.  homeowner was advised to not run any water untill plumber clears the blockage in lateral.

SPILL_LOC_DESC: The private clean out is near one of the three warehouses on the property.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: The spill was contained in a drain inlet box (did not reach a pipe) and on the concrete area at a loadind dock.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: The power to the lift station had been shut off during building maintenance. The maintenance person failed to turn the breaker back on when the job was completed. The built up pressure in the full system was relieved at the lowest clean out.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Restored flow;Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: A plumber was called to the site determined the reason for the spill was lift station failure. A sewage pumping company responded and removed a large portion of the sewage from the lift station to stop the spill and give the responing crews time to make repairs. The property manager then called an electrician to trace the problem. The electrician traced the problem to the circuit breaker box that had been turned off. When the power was restored to the pumps they began running and removed the accumulated sewage.

WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: Private lateral. Public Works employee observed sewage spill beginning on sidewalk and responded immediately.  Flow was minimal.  The motel manager was directed to stop all water use.  Initial spill was approx. 5 gallons.  After crews cleaned up, someone in the motel likely flushed a toilet and another 2 gallons spilled.  After crews cleaned that up, Mr. Rooter came to unclog the line and approx. 20 gallons spilled in the unclogging of the line of which our crews cleaned up.

SPILL_LOC_DESC: Grease trap overflow
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: Grease trap overflowed into flower bed
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Flower bed surrounding the grease trap
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Sewer lateral is plugged downstream of the grease trap and past the tee connecting the grease trap effluent with the remainder of the sewage from the restaurant.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Owner pumped grease trap Monday 8/29/16 due to grease trap over flow. Grease trap overflowed again Wednesday 8/31/6. Grease trap maintenance company notified owner's representative that sewage was flowing into the grease trap from the outlet. City of Arvin was then notified that the City main line may be blocked. City's contractor, Veolia, responded and found the City main was flowing freely upstream and downstream of the restaurant. Informed owner's representative that the problem was in the main line and surmised the blockage was after the grease trap discharge and the rest of the restaurant sewage connect.

RETURN_TO_SSS: Not Applicable - Spill did not reach a separate storm drainpipe

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system;Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: On Sunday, January 30, 2011 at approximately 0800 a mainline clog resulted in a sewer overflow from the back of Building 322.  The clog was cleared by staff who were already on grounds for an unrelated maintenance issue.  The total volume of overflow was approximately 500 gallons, however, an earthen barrier was established by responding staff, which prevented any contamination of the Storm Drain System, estimated.    The 500 gallon overflow increased in volume by an additional 500-700 gallons of rainwater.  All of the overflow/contaminated rainwater was pumped back into the sanitary sewer system through a nearby cleanout, and the soil and residual water has been treated with a granular chlorine sanitizer.

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: On Friday, September 9, 2011 at approximately 1730, a mainline clog resulted in a sewer overflow from the back of Building 353.  The clog was cleared by a staff member who was called in to correct the problem.  The overflow occured inside a containment established by the responding staff prior to opening a clean-out to clear the blockage.  The total volume of overflow was approximately 60 gallons, however, the sandbag barrier established by responding staff prevented any contamination of the Storm Drain System.  All but aproximately one-half gallon of water was pumped back into the sewer system.

RETURN_TO_SSS: Yes
SPILL_LOC_DESC: Private Apartment Community
FINAL_SPILL_DEST: Separate storm drain;Street/curb and gutter;Surface water
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Santa Ana River
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: FOG deposition in the private sewer lines.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Restored flow;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Sewage overflowed from a private sewer manhole to an on-site storm drain. City staff arrived and began containing the spill on-site with a Vactor truck. A second City Vactor began opening manholes on the property to determine the location of the obstruction in the private sewer line. The second Vactor cleared the private line to mitigate the overflow. A private plumber showed up shortly after the obstruction was cleared and began jetting the private system.    City staff washed down the spill site and collected the sewage / wash water in a Vactor truck. County of Orange staff located where the storm drain line entered the Santa Ana River and discovered sewage ponded at the outfall. City staff responded to the location with a Vactor truck and collected the sewage from the river bed.

RETURN_TO_SSS: No
SPILL_LOC_DESC: Apartment Complex
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Santa Ana River
WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: Private sewer line on the property.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Restored flow;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: City of Orange was notified of the spill by the property management at aproximately 7:30 AM. Upon arrival, City of Orange discovered spill was within Anaheim's jurisdiction and notified Anaheim Public Works. Note: The property is split between the Cities of Anaheim and Orange.    City of Anaheim staff contained the spill on-site with two Vactor trucks while the property coordinated with a plumbing company to clear the obstruction from the private sewer line. City of Anaheim staff confirmed that the lost sewage had ponded at a storm drain outfall in the Santa Ana River and notified Orange County Public Works (agency with jurisdiction over the river). In order to mitigate the overflow, a City Vactor was used to clear the private sewer line to restore flow before the private plumber arrived. City staff washed down the spill area to the Vactor trucks.     County fo Orange initiated clean-up response in the Santa Ana River. A private contractor, American Integrated, was contacted by the County to collected the spilled sewage and contaminated water in the river bed.  Two 4500 gallon capacity pumper trucks were used intially to collect the spill until a bypass system could be established. American Integrated used a pump system to begin pumping out the river bed to an Orange County Sanitation District (OCSD) sewer line that runs parallel to the river. The entire ponded area was pumped out by approximately 11:00 PM. Approximately 75,000 gallons of water was removed from the ponded area.

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: City Fire Department used 3,000 gallons of water and flushed the wastewater to the storm drain.  The Collection Crew was able to remove about 500 gallons of the diluted material.  The wastewater entered a catch basin 1,073 feet from the home. No evidence was present of any wastewater upstream or downstream

RETURN_TO_SSS: No
SPILL_LOC_DESC: An investigation revealed the spill coming phyically from several cleanouts and the grease trap that belongs to the restaurant located at 26589 Highland Ave, cross street Victoria Ave and flowing into a cross gutter across the parking lot and into a catch basin.  The outlet of the catch basin heads south on Victoria Ave. to a Caltrans storm drain facility along the 210 Freeway then outlets into Warm Creek flood control channel.  Due to the secure nature of Caltrans storm drain, sewage could not be verified in Warm Creek.

FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Fifteen gallons entered the catch basin inlet.  Crews placed sandbags inside of the catch basin inlet to prevent the spillage from entering the storm drainpipe.  Crews inspected the downstream storm drainpipe and it was dry.  The spill was contained inside of the catch basin inlet.  Crews then vacuumed and washed the catch basin inlet. Crews returned the waste and wash water back into the sewer system.

They will enforce the City's FOG ordinance with the surrounding Food Service Establishments as well as property management. District crews hydrojetted the line again on 2011-08-22 to ensure it was as clean as possible.  District crews video inspected the lateral with a push camera and observed a sag in the line.

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system;Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: There have been several private spills in this complex. This information was given to the Garden Grove Environmental Management Team. They will continue to enforce the City's FOG ordinance with property management. Additionally attached to a letter dated March 1, 2010 to Lamplighter Village Apartments:  A CCTV inspection performed by Arrow Drain and Plumbing indicated multiple lateral line locations with sags and tree root intrusion. Due to these findings Lamplighter Village Apartments is required per Section 6.20.025 of the GGSD Code of Regulations to repair all structural deficiencies on the property with in 60 (sixty) days of receiving this letter. Please be advised that due to the frequency of spills you have had and the lack of notification Lamplighter management has made to appropriate agencies during sewer spills, your case file is being forwarded to our City/District attorney. Forwarding of your package to the City/District Attorney subjects your business to fines and penalties.

RETURN_TO_SSS: No
SPILL_LOC_DESC: Private cleanout in the parking lot.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Westminster channel.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Inspected sewer using CCTV to determine cause;Restored flow;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system;Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: District crews asked the business owners and workers at the complex to find out exactly when the overflow started. Some workers stated that they noticed sewer odors since Saturday 4/28/12. Other businesses do not have bathrooms so they did not notice any problems. Some people did not even know there was a spill. The original caller  Mehdi  was contacted and he said the overflow occurred when he called at 2:07 PM.   The flow was intermittent but very light. Given the fact that it took at least 53 minutes (2:07 PM to 3:00 PM) to overflow 11 gallons in the parking lot, the estimate of 5 gallons lost seems accurate since it would take time for the flow to reach the catch basin inlet.  District crews video inspected the lateral using a push camera and found a sag in the pipe approximately 5 feet downstream of the cleanout nearest Galway St.

RETURN_TO_SSS: Yes

APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: Planter area next to the building.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system;Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: District crews instructed property management to call a plumber to clear the blockage and determine the reason for the discharge into the soil.  Bennett's Plumbing cleared the blockage with a drain cleaning cable. The plumber returned and inspected the line on 2012-06-26 using a push camera and found a break in the kitchen line under a sink.  This is causing the line to back up and leak into the soil beneath the slab.  The plumber gave an estimate to repair the pipe to property management.  The Garden Grove Environmental Management Team will enforce the City's FOG ordinance and will make sure repairs are made to the pipe.

RETURN_TO_SSS: No
SPILL_LOC_DESC: The estimated flow rate is 5GPM as of 7:30am (an estimated 600 gallons entered the storm drain). The District placed sandbags to stop the flow from entering the storm drain and called the Health Department. The city water department shut off the water at 8am and Ocean Blue arrived at this point.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: The estimated flow rate is 5GPM as of 7:30am (an estimated 600 gallons entered the storm drain). The District placed sandbags to stop the flow from entering the storm drain and called the Health Department. The city water department shut off the water at 8am and Ocean Blue arrived at this point.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: When the plumber has broken through the stoppage and dumped an excessive amount of FOG and rags in the MCSD's sewer main causing a small spill. MCSD will remain on site until the plumber finishes thoroughly cleaning the lateral and we are assured that no more grease and rags enters into our sewer system. This was the safest alternative. We did not want the grease to continue to spill into the parking lot where it can be track by cars, into the public-right-away and possibly causing an accident or injury.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-Up;Mitigated Effects of Spill;Contained all or portion of spill;Returned Portion of Spill to Sanitary Sewer System;Property Owner Notified;Other Enforcement Agency Notified
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: 1) OCFA calls MCSD Emergency phone @ 5:45am  2) Cody calls Nick @ 5:50am  3) Nick calls City of Westminster @ approximately 6am. (City of Westminster calls Ocean Blue) Nicks district vehicle was not equipped with spill containment tools. District corrected that the next day and added more sandbags to each emergency vehicle.  4) MCSD returns @ 6:30am with T5 work truck to contain spill on property. BMW was parked in front of the storm drain with the tires touching the curb. MCSD could not use neoprene mat to contain spill. MCSD uses its four sandbags to contain spill at curb approximately 30 feet east of the storm drain.  5) At 7am spill over comes the sandbag containment. MCSD starts to add dirt from planter trying to contain it.  6) At 7:26am MCSD calls OCHCA.  7) At 7:30am City of Westminster shows up with Ocean Blue. Ocean Blue takes over containment.  8) At 8am City of Westminster, Water Department shuts off the water.  9) At approximately 8am plumber arrives.  10) At 8:42am MCSD, M63 Vactor trucks arrives to control debris being pushed into the MCSD sewer system. Vactor crew is on scene for 95 minutes until 10:17am. Vactor crew made sure that the plumber was fully completed with his cleaning of the private lateral then the Vactor crew proceeded to clean the District sewer main on Westminster Blvd.    Note: MCSD was the first to arrive and last to leave.

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: When MCSD arrived the City of Westminster already had the spell contained and water turned off. MCSD only assisted in cleaning the public right-of way.

SPILL_LOC_NAME: 901 East Fairway BLVD, Big Bear City CA (Manhole #21)
RETURN_TO_SSS: Not Applicable - Spill did not reach a separate storm drainpipe
SPILL_LOC_DESC: Main Trunk Line manhole #21, at the corner of Teal Street and Fairway BLVD.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: not applicable
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Flow exceeded capacity of sewer main trunk line. Member agency satellite system flow exceeded capacity of the main sewer trunk line, due to excessive inflow and infiltration entering the sewer system.
WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: There was no failure of the system, flow exceeded capacity of sewer trunk line and the excess flow spilled from manhole #21.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Due to the slope of the pipe and the proximity to elbows this section of the trunk line has reduced capacity. Therefore, our agency set up two (2) by pass pumps at the location to pump the sewage pass this section of pipeline. The sewage was pumped from manhole's #21 and #22 to downstream manholes.

RETURN_TO_SSS: Not Applicable - Spill did not reach a separate storm drainpipe
SPILL_LOC_DESC: Private parking lot of condominum association
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Mechanical failure in private backwater valve-This valve was replaced three days later by a contracted plumber.  Robert Koczko, CVWD Sewer Maintenance Foreman, received a call of a sewer backup 9685 Northampton Street at approximately 9:00pm. Call came directly to Koczko from Al Otine District Stand-by person. Koczko immediately responded to the District yard while Al called Shawn Spromberg and Gabe Parisi to respond in Vactors 271 and 234 to the location.  Koczko and Spromberg  arrived on site by 9:15 pm to contain and control the situation.  Al was able to find the downstream manhole to set up  Vactor 271 (Parisi) to clear the blockage, while Koczko and Spromberg set up  Vactor 234  in the complex to contain and Vacuum the spill. This system is a private 8-inch sewer with a private Backwater Valve before it enters our public system.  The problem was the back water valve which was stuck obstructing the upstream flow, creating the blockage.  Al Otine and Parisi jetted to backwater valve hitting the flapper approximately 10 times before flow was restored which was approximately 9:30pm.     Vactor 234, (Koczko) was set up in the condo comlplex with the curb and gutter diked with dirt to contain the spill.  Vactor 234 Vacuum tube was set up in the private gutter catch basin to contain and collect spill.  We continued to flush the affected curb and gutter area and collected it at the containment area.  Approximately 500 gallons was spilled, collected and returned to the sewer collection system along with wash down water.  Clean up procedures lasted until 10:00 pm, with the crews in the yard by 10:30pm    The crew continued to inspect the private upstream and downstream sewer manholes to confirm flow was restored. We found that 2 m.h upstream there was a construction debris trap lodged in the line.  Koczko spoke to the management company CMS-Mike, of this private community.  Koczko explained that a plumber would need to be contacted to inspect their back water valve, and possibly clean and inspect their sewer collection system.  On Tuesday, April 24, 2012, District crews cctv the line and found that the backwater valve was off its hinge and needed replacement.  I informed Mike from CMS and the Backwater valve was replaced on Thursday, April 26, 2012.      All agencies were notified by 11:00 pm     Notified the customer to hire contractor to inspect and clean sewer system.    ****Cause of blockage to be stuck private back water valve******        OES notified at 10:50pm, CN#12-2427, RWQCB notified at 10:55pm left message, email to City of Rancho Cucamonga
WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: at the back water valve, also found a debris sand trap lodged in the private sewer system which we removed
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Inspected sewer using CCTV to determine cause;Restored flow;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Besides contain, control, clean up and communicate spill to agencies, we made the association make the necessary repairs

RETURN_TO_SSS: Yes
SPILL_LOC_DESC: The spill was located south of the Rancho Center parking lot, directly behind Zendejas Restaurant.
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: Spill was coming from a 4-inch private sewer cleanout.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Response and/or Action Taken by Agencies  Date:  Tuesday, May 1, 2012    Robert Koczko received a call of a sewer spill at 9059 San Bernardino from George Rodriguez, CVWD Operations Superintendent, on 5/1/12 at approximately 3:24pm.  The spill occurred in a private sewer system in a parking lot located at the City of Rancho Recreation facility.  Koczko called two Vactor crews to respond, with Koczko on site by 3:35pm.  Koczko saw a spill at less than 5GPM from a 4-inch clean out in the private parking lot and immediately set up a containment area at a storm drain inlet by way of dirt dam.  Vactor 271 showed up 5 minutes later and was set up at containment area to vacuum up spill and to control.  Since wastewater made it in the private storm drain system, all efforts were made to contain it.  Vactor 173 arrived on site by 3:45pm and set up to contain/vacuum the spill in the storm drain system, approximately 1200-feet downstream, at Foothill and Lion. Mike Moore, City of Rancho Cucamonga Environmental Programs Inspector, was on site and made the initial call to CVWD.  Rancho Plumbing was on site working to clear the blockage in the private lateral.  Plumber did not clear the blockage until 5:45 pm, however the spill was contained and controlled by both vactor crews.  Directly upstream from the spill point was Zendejas Restaurant, which was where the spill flow was coming from.  Koczko asked them to stop using water until line was cleared at approximately 4:00pm.  Koczko also called Eric Johnson, CVWD Industrial Waste Inspector, to inspect the restaurant grease interceptor.  Cause of blockage was unknown.      An estimate of spill was at 5GPM for 60 minutes until contained.  Approximately 300 gallons made its way into the private storm drain with 200 gallons collected.  District staff flushed the storm drain system and collected all washdown water at the storm drain by Lion and Foothill, returning it to the collection system.      All affected areas in the parking lot were washed down and contained, collected and returned to the sewer collection system.        OES notified at 5:23pm control #12-2630, RWQCB notified by message at 5:28pm.  City of Rancho NPDES was on site.       *****PLEASE NOTE:  PRIVATE SEWER SPILL.******* Responsible party Safco Capitol.  Tom Klugman-P.M.  Cell 310-479-6069, Office:  310-473-9500

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Robert Koczko, CVWD Sewer Maintenance Foreman, received a call of a sewer backup 9713 Baseline Rd at approximately 10:10 am. Call came directly to Koczko from Pete Peters, District Stand-by person for the week. Koczko immediately called Al Otine and David Scott at 10:12am tor respond to the District yard.  Koczko and David arrived on site by 10:35 am to contain and control the situation.  Dave set up Vactor 271 on downstream MH3952 to relieve the private backwater valve and restore, while Koczko and Otine set up  Vactor 173  in at the storm drain catch basin east side Archibald, north of Church contain and Vacuum the spill.   Since the spill reached the storm drain, all efforts where made to contain and collect from the storm drain.  Dave set up Vactor 271 in a storm drain manhole on Church at Kahai.  Once containment point was set in the storm drain, we flushed approximately 4,300 feet of curb, gutter, catch basin and storm drain pipe and collected all water/wastewater with the vactor vacuum, returning all back to collection system.      This system is a private 8-inch sewer with a private Backwater Valve before it enters our public system.  The problem was the back water valve which was stuck obstructing the upstream flow, creating the blockage.  David Scott jetted to backwater valve  60-feet hitting the flapper 1 time before flow was restored which was approximately 10:35am.     Approximately 2200 gallons was spilled, collected and returned to the sewer collection system along with the wash down water.  Clean up procedures lasted until 12:00 pm, with the crews in the yard by 12:10 pm      All agencies were notified by 12:15 pm June 9, 2012

APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: spill point was a 4-inch sewer cleanout
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: spill cause was debris lodged behind private backwater valve.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Contained all or portion of spill;Inspected sewer using CCTV to determine cause;Restored flow
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Robert Koczko, CVWD Sewer Maintenance Foreman and on-call person, received a call of a sewer backup at 8480 Carson at approximately 3:37pm. Koczko immediately called Gabe Parisi  to respond to the District yard and return with Vactor 234 to this location.  Koczko was on site by 3:45pm, identified the sewer system as a private system and inspected all manholes on site to see where the problem was.  The problem was identified as a failure in the private backwater valve which is located on private property west of Baker north of Arrow.  Koczko made every attempt to notify management company of the situation since this was a private system and not the Districts responsibility.  Since we had no response from the management compay, the District action and restored flow by Jet rodding the line from the District sewer to the private backwater valve.  The jet rodder is used to bump the flapper valve, get it to move, allowing the debris and wastewater to flow through it.  We retrieved PVC pipe, wood stakes, rocks, rags and grease which was a contributor to the blockage stuck behind the flapper valve.  Less than 100 gallons of waste water spilled onto the property.      Once the system was restored to normal flow, Koczko proceeded to inspect the upstream private sewer manholes.  The manholes upstream had channels full of grease  and debris, also found one manhole structure that had lumber in the channels obstructing the flow.

FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Date:  Thursday, September 27, 2012    Robert Koczko, CVWD Sewer Maintenance Foreman, received a call of a sewer backup 9651 Baseline Rd at approximately 11:45 am. Call came directly to Koczko from Pat Milroy, District Water Maintenance Forman.   Koczko immediately called Gabe Parisi, Randy Stewart and Mike Asuega at 11:47am to respond with Vactor 234, Traffic Control 325, and response van 322. We arrived on site by 12:00pm to contain and control the PRIVATE SPILL.  Randy and Gabe set up Vactor 234 1200-feet south of the spill area at the curb and gutter to set up barrier and contain the spill.  Mike and Robert Koczko, proceeded to clear the blockage through the private 6-inch cleanout using a rooter-snake.  Blockage was cleared by 12:05pm, blockage was grease 65-feet in on the private line.  The private parking lot, and 1200-feet of curb and gutter were flushed by the upstream hydrant using a diffuser, with all water/waste water being collected at the containment area and returned to the collection system.      Again, this is a PRIVATE 6-inch sewer system, with the problem being grease on the customers side.  I notified the management company, and explained that a plumbing contractor will need to assess, maintain and make necessary repairs as needed.  I explained that they will be back charged for our services and a state report has been issued.         All agencies were notified by 2:35 pm September 27, 2012     Notified the customer to hire contractor to inspect and clean sewer system.    ****Cause of blockage to grease in private 6-inch system******    Responsible Party:  Management Company:  Pacific West         319D Airport Dr.                  Costa Mesa, CA       Contact:  Lanise, 714-433-7300    Mailing Address:  P.O. RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Al Otine, CVWD Sewer Maintenance Worker III, received a call of a sewer backup 9713 Baseline Rd at approximately 10:05 am. Call came directly to Al from Jeff Guerin, Water Maintenance Worker II who was first responder. Al Otine and the crew arrived  on site by 10:15 am to contain and control the situation.  Al and Alex set up Vactor 271 on downstream MH3952 to relieve the private backwater valve and restore, while Dave and Wilson set up  Vactor 335  in at the storm drain catch basin east side Archibald, north of Church contain and Vacuum the spill.   All efforts were made to contain and collect wastewater from the gutter,and catch basin by containing and flushing, collecting water/wastewater and returning to the collection system.    This system is a private 8-inch sewer with a private Backwater Valve before it enters our public system.  The problem was the back water valve which was stuck obstructing the upstream flow, creating the blockage.  Al Otine jetted to backwater valve  60-feet hitting the flapper before flow was restored which was approximately 10:15am.     Approximately 1500 gallons was spilled with 1000 entering the storm drain, collected and returned to the sewer collection system along with the wash down water.  Clean up procedures lasted until 11:00 am, with the crews in the yard by 11:10 am      All agencies were notified by 11:15 am May 24, 2013    I spoke with Tina Lee, Manager, and will have plumber meet me on site to go over what and where the problem lies.      Responsible Party:  Packo Investments          3435 Wilshire Blvd. #1710          Los Angeles, CA 90010      C/O Tina Lee

SPILL_LOC_DESC: Responded to a call that sewer grease was coming out of a manhole in the parking lot/drive in front of Tasty Goody Chinese restaraunt.   Dispatched CVWD sewer crews with 2 vactor trucks and myself (Shawn Spromberg- Maintenance Supervisor of Wastewater Collections)  I made contact with Kai (manager).  CVWD washed down the area, recollected wash down water and re-distributed it back to the sewer system via a downstream manhole.  We also stayed onsite until All American Plumbing arrived to hydrojet/inspect the lateral line/interceptor.  *Spill was completely contained to the drive area parking lot and fully washed down/recollected*** our inspection (manholes up-downstream showed mainline sewer functioning ok- problem isolated to areas of interceptors/sample box and lateral piping to main connection.***Private Lateral Discharge caused by grease build up in lateral line-responsible party=Tasty Goody. Control#15-0472

Once issue(slow draining/grease coming from manhole) water to drain was stopped, discharge slowed/stopped seeping out of lids/covers. CVWD was notified and we were dispatched to clean/wash down area.

SPILL_LOC_NAME: Public Storage, 5548 Arrow Hwy., Montclair, CA 91763
RETURN_TO_SSS: Not Applicable - Spill did not reach a separate storm drainpipe
SPILL_LOC_DESC: Clean out in parking lot area
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Grass Storm Water infiltration basin
WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: Approximately 30 feet from sewer clean out where spill was visible.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Restored flow;Other (specify below)
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: At 2:25 pm Public Storage District manager Rick Jansen noticed wastewater coming from a cleanout in the parking area.  Onsite manager John Adams contacted City of Montclair Public Works Administrative Analysy Alicia Johnson at 3:05pm.  Ms. Johnson contacted Public Works Superintendant Xavier Mendez and Environmental Manager Nicole Greene at 3:06pm.  Mr. Mendez sent Field Maintenance Workers Ron Baron and Eddy Chavez to the site.  Barron and Chavez arrived at 3:15pm and evaluated the spill.  At 3:20-3:30pm Baron and Chavez jetted the main sewer line in both directions and determined that the blockage was not in the City Main line.  No flow had entered the stormdrain/curb and gutter.  All wastewater from the clean out flowed into an onsite grass storm water infiltration basin.  No solid waste or toilet paper was visable.  Environmental Manager Nicole Greene and Environmental Compliance Inspector Tanya Honeycutt arrived onsite at 3:30pm and made contact with Rick Jansen and John Adams.  The employees were notified that the blockage is in the lateral, and that a plumber needed to be contacted immediately to resolve the issue.  Greene and Honeycutt requried all water usage on the property to be suspended until the later was cleared and flow restored.  Plumber Paul Jenkin from Paul Jenkin Plumbing arrived onsite at 6:20 pm and the blockage was removed at 6:44pm by rodding the line.  The blockage was determined to be approximately 30 feet in the lateral from the clean out where the spill was visable and was determined to be caused by rags/debris (feminine hygine products).Flow was restored as required.

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Sewer Maintenance Workers arrived onsite and cleared the blockage.  The blockage was caused by construction debris in the mainline and manhole that came from the Metro Honda Service Center construction addition project.  Once debris was removed and flow was restored the small amount of flow that had entered the storm drain inlet was recovered  at the City of Montclair Storm Drain interceptor located at Palo Verde Avenue.  That captured flow was returned to the City of Montclair Sewer System.  The 30 foot section of storm drain curb and gutter was disinfected and cleaned and all cleaning wash water was discharged to the sewer system.  Approximately 10 gallons of wastewater from the spill evaporated in the curb and gutter prior to cleaning and disinfection that had not been recovered.

SPILL_LOC_DESC: South side of building at grease interceptor for  14091 Newport Ave.
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: Spill came from grease interceptor outlet chamber access manhole.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST: Drainage Channel;Separate Storm Drain;Street/Curb and Gutter
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Spill travelled from grease interceptor manhole to surface drain in parking lot in front of pizzeria establishment.  Surface drain discharged to curb and gutter and then to storm drain catch basin.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: The outlet Tee on the grease interceptor was missing and later discovered to be laying in the bottom of the grease interceptor.
SSO_PLSD_SOURCE_EXPLAIN: There are 4 FSEs that share one grease interceptor at this location.
WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: The failure occurred within the grease interceptor.  The outlet tee was not in place.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-Up;Mitigated Effects of Spill;Contained all or portion of spill
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Our staff vacuumed out the grease interceptor (approximately 2,000 gallons)  to prevent the spill from continuing while OCHCA worked with the property manager and businesses to stop discharging into the grease interceptor.  The parking lot was then vacuumed along with the parking lot surface drain and storm water catch basin (approximately 600 gallons).  Our staff then coordinated with County Staff from OC Storm Water who identified a storm drain manhole where grease could be seen floating on top of water.  Our crew vacuumed up approximately 9,200 gallons of water from the storm drain in an effort to remove as much grease as possible.

SPILL_LOC_DESC: The spill overflowed out of the private sewer lateral, located northwest of the property at the drive thru entrance.
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: The spill overflowed out of the private lateral onto the street westward down about 200 feet in a storm drain.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-up (mitigated effects of spill);Contained all or portion of spill;Returned all or portion of spill to sanitary sewer system
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: City crews were working approx. 100 feet west of the storm drain that the spill went into. They were able to capture a large amount of the spill by placing a few BMPs (geo-logs) along the gutter and notified city's dispatch.  The first combination vehicle (#1) set up a this storm drain; they contained, vacuumed and decontaminated the spill in the street and gutter. Another combo vehicle (#2) set up at the third storm drain inlet downstream, about 450 feet from the first crew to meet and capture the spillage traveling down the storm drain. After unplugging the lateral and cleaning all the spillage on the street, they then proceeded to dump about 400-500 gallons of water down the storm drain to clean the storm drainpipes.  The crew (#2) downstream was able to vacuum all of the water, there was 100% containment and full recovery of the sewer spill.

City crews tracked  the SSO in the storm drain and went ahead of the SSO approximately 1200 feet west of the overflow to capture all of the spillage. They cleaned all storm drain basins and then flushed the storm drainpipes by dumping 600-700 gallons of water with a crew downstream to vacuum all the water.

SPILL_LOC_NAME: In Alley Between Second and Third Streets
RETURN_TO_SSS: Not Applicable - Spill did not reach a separate storm drainpipe

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-Up;Contained all or portion of spill;Returned Portion of Spill to Sanitary Sewer System;Property Owner Notified
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: At 10:15am, we received a call regarding a private spill that was ocurring in the alley behind 237 Third Street. The field supervisor arrived onsite at 10:40 am and the spill had stopped. we tried to locate a homeowner, but nobody was home. After further investigation, we learned that the home is a vacation rental and the temporary tenats had left for the day. We were able to locate the homeowner in Belgim. a call was made to him and within an hour, a plumber arrived and clear the private lateral. At approximately 10:42 am, we notified our City combination sewer cleaner crew to resond and clean up any remainig water and debris that was evedent (approximately 15 gallons). All clean up debris and water was returned to the sewer system. We estimate that 5 gallons of water evaporated from the pavement. At 11:25am, the problem was resolved, cleaned up and all returned to normal.

RETURN_TO_SSS: No
SPILL_LOC_DESC: The cleanout servicing 1595 Regatta Road was spilling over onto the driveway and out onto the Starlit Drive.
APPEAR_PT_EXPLAIN: The residents cleanout lid was off in the driveway to prevent any future back up into her home until their lateral repair was finished.
FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: All wastewater that entered the storm drain on Starlit Drive was eventually redirected into the sewer collection system by the CDS unit at Bluebird Canyon.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: The resident had been experiencing plumbing issues a few days before and called SL Plumbing to resolve her issues. They had hydro-jetted her line to get her service back and had scheduled to have a liner installed for her lateral the first week of December.  After speaking with the owner of SL Plumbing (Steve Lewis 949-201-6594) he acknowledged that when they cleaned the lateral they did not retrieve any roots in the downstream manhole. He also agreed they had left her cleanout off in the drive way to prevent any future back up into her home until the repair was finished. It is my estimation that this overflow was caused by the root mass protruding from the lateral that services this residence.
SSO_PLSD_SOURCE_EXPLAIN: Single Family Home and no one was home at time of arrival.
WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: SL Plumbing hydro-jetted her line to clear her private lateral service and had scheduled to have a liner installed for her lateral the first week of December.  These lateral roots unfortunately had remained in the lateral protruding out into the main line causing main line flow to back up into the lateral line and within the city main line itself.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-Up;Mitigated Effects of Spill;Restored flow;Property Owner Notified
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: To ensure the manhole would not eventually overflow, staff immediately set up truck #200 on Morningside Drive and jetted from manhole (I19-072) upstream to manhole (I19-069).  The flow in the city mainline was restored by 18:55.  Clean up consisted of the staff washing and vacuuming the affected areas.

RETURN_TO_SSS: Not Applicable - Spill did not reach a separate storm drainpipe

FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: Front yard of the property at 278 Ruby Street
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: According to the CCTV inspection, the private lateral sewer discharge was caused by main line flow be diverted into the service line of 278 Ruby Street from protruding roots out of an abandoned 278 Ruby Street lateral downstream of their active connection.
SSO_PLSD_SOURCE_EXPLAIN: The crew responded by jetting the main line in front of the property to determine if the cause of the discharge was in the Citys main line.  Staff used Truck 191 to jet the main line and found that the jetting tool was hitting protruding lateral roots in front 278 Ruby Street twenty five feet up from the downstream manhole.
WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: Main line due to protruding roots from an abandoned 278 Ruby Street lateral
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-Up;Mitigated Effects of Spill;Contained all or portion of spill
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Staff cleaned the affected area and all residual wastewater soaked into to the front yard.

There was a beach closure issued on Monday, December 15, 2014, from Brooks Street to Pearl Street, the closure was lifted on Wednesday, December 17, 2014, after beach samplings came back negative and the Hotel confirmed their fixed private lateral.
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: Liner installation failed when it was being installed on the lateral servicing the Surf and Sand Hotel
WHERE_FAIL_OCCUR_EXP: Staff was told that the Hotel had plumbing issues on Friday, December 12, 2014, and had hired a plumbing contractor to install a liner in their own private sewer system.  The liner installation failed and resulted in wastewater spilling out into the Hotels parking structure.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Other Enforcement Agency Notified
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: Orange County Health , OES (Office of Emergency Services) and San Diego regional Water Quality Control Board notified.

FINAL_SPILL_DEST_EXPL: The City of National City had a private lateral sewage discharge reported on May 24, 2016 at approximately 10:00 AM at 1410 Sherryl Lane of approximately 30 gallons. The spill reached an open concrete lined culvert, and was not fully recovered. It is estimated 25 gallons were not recoverable. Our Environmental Consultant was out onsite, and from a visual inspection, no body of water was impacted. Additionally, there were no visible signs of contaminated water as the discharge was traced downstream by following our storm drain network.     The sewer crew contained, and cleaned the spill prior to leaving the site.     No further investigation is required.
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES: Cleaned-Up;Property Owner Notified;Other Enforcement Agency Notified
RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: The San Diego Regional Water Board was contacted within 24 hours.

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: CITY OF VISTA CREWS RESPONDED TO SPILL; USED DIRT TO BERM THE CURB AND GUTTER TO PREVENT FURTHER SEWAGE ENTERING THE STORM DRAIN. WASHED DOWN THE STREET, CURB AND GUTTER; VACUUMED THE WASHDOWN FROM THE STREET, CURB AND GUTTER; VACUUMED THE STORM DRAIN CULVERT AND BOX DRAIN INLET; THEN VACUUMED THE SEWAGE THAT WAS CONTAINED IN THE CREEKBED. STORM DRAIN ENFORCEMENT OFFICER FARLOW WAS PRESENT AND SPOKE WITH PROPERTY MANAGEMENT TO INFORM THEM THEN NEED TO FIX THEIR PRIVATE LATERAL/CLEAN OUT FROM SPILLING

RETURN_TO_SSS: Yes
SPILL_LOC_DESC: SEWER COMING FROM A PRIVATE MANHOLE LOCATED ON THE PROPERTY OF THE WATERLEAF APARTMENT HOMES
SPILL_CAUSE_EXPLAIN: LARGE AMOUNT OF ROOTS IN PRIVATE MANHOLE. THE PRIVATE MANHOLE WAS BURIED AND THE APARTMENT MANAGER WAS UNAWARE OF THE EXISTENCE OF THE MANHOLE. IT WAS UNBURIED BY THE LANDSCAPER AND THE MANHOLE AND AREA SURROUNDING MANHOLE WAS FILLED WITH SEWAGE
SSO_PLSD_SOURCE_PLSD: High Density Residential (5 or more units - Apartments, Condos, etc.)

RESPONSE_ACTIVITIES_EXPL: THE SPILL REACHED THE CURB AND GUTTER AND CITY CREWS WASHED DOWN AND CAPTURED ALL OF THE WASHDOWN. THE STORM DRAIN WAS RINSED AND CAPTURED. THE APARTMENT MANAGER CALLED A PLUMBER AND THEY CLEARED THE BLOCKAGE FROM THEIR UPSTREAM MANHOLE. THE CITY OF VISTA'S STORMWATER CREW WAS ON SCENE AND AN N.O.V. WAS ISSUED
